review.title: Distributed Constraint Problems for Utilitarian Agents with Privacy Concerns, Recast as POMDPs
review.abstract: Privacy has traditionally been a major motivation for distributed problem solving. Distributed Constraint Satisfaction Problem (DisCSP) as well as Distributed Constraint Optimization Problem (DCOP) are fundamental models used to solve various families of distributed problems. Even though several approaches have been proposed to quantify and preserve privacy in such problems, none of them is exempt from limitations. Here we approach the problem by assuming that computation is performed among utilitarian agents. We introduce a utilitarian approach where the utility of each state is estimated as the difference between the reward for reaching an agreement on assignments of shared variables and the cost of privacy loss. We investigate extensions to solvers where agents integrate the utility function to guide their search and decide which action to perform, defining thereby their policy. We show that these extended solvers succeed in significantly reducing privacy loss without significant degradation of the solution quality.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: While many approaches have recently been proposed for dealing with privacy in distributed constraints satisfaction and optimization problems, none of them are exempt from constraints. These approaches require certain characteristics of the original problem or can only take certain aspects of privacy into account. In this work, we propose the Utilitarianism Distributed Constrained Problem (UDisCP) framework, which models the loss of privacy for the disclosure of an agent's limitations as a utility function, with agents integrating privacy requirements directly into their search process. Then, the solution to the problem is to find the best compromise between solution quality and data loss, rather than just focusing on solution quality. We propose extensions of existing algorithms for DisCSPs (SyncBTU, ABTU) and DCOPs (DBOU, DSAU, and ADOPTU) that agents use privacy information to change their behavior and reduce their search process by suggesting the extent of the data loss to others, and suggesting the problems with the data loss.

metadata.abstractText: Privacy has traditionally been a major motivation for distributed problem solving. Distributed Constraint Satisfaction Problem (DisCSP) as well as Distributed Constraint Optimization Problem (DCOP) are fundamental models used to solve various families of distributed problems. Even though several approaches have been proposed to quantify and preserve privacy in such problems, none of them is exempt from limitations. Here we approach the problem by assuming that computation is performed among utilitarian agents. We introduce a utilitarian approach where the utility of each state is estimated as the difference between the reward for reaching an agreement on assignments of shared variables and the cost of privacy loss. We investigate extensions to solvers where agents integrate the utility function to guide their search and decide which action to perform, defining thereby their policy. We show that these extended solvers succeed in significantly reducing privacy loss without significant degradation of the solution quality.
